author: sky.cactus
content: Will create2 address output change if we move to 32 byte addresses?

author: pauld.9606
content: The magician's post proposes "a new opcode, CREATE3, that is capable of generating 32 byte addresses."

author: pauld.9606
content: I am guessing we want to avoid semantics changes to CREATE2.

author: pauld.9606
content: Because every semantics change can break something.

author: pauld.9606
content: We can get around semantics changes by inventing some indirection/abstraction-layer/compatibility-layer which is outside of current semantics. The magician's post proposes such a solution with a translation table, but I'm not sure how this would work with CREATE2.

author: .vbuterin
content: the translation table approach would work with any old-style address

author: pauld.9606
content: Are we considering extending CREATE2 semantics to also interact with the translation table?

author: pauld.9606
content: Just thinking briefly, we would have to handle table collisions somehow. I would have to think more about this.

author: .vbuterin
content: when would there be table collisions? Like, if someone does the 2**80 work to make one?

author: pauld.9606
content: Yes, precisely the motivation for longer addresses.

author: .vbuterin
content: I guess in that case, the table would just keep the older value, and the second address that maps to the same compressed address would just not be able to properly interact with old-style accounts

author: pauld.9606
content: Makes sense. This disincentivizes doing the 2^80 work. But creates a pathological case that people should check for collisions before deploying.

author: .vbuterin
content: At least for a while, until all the contracts migrate over to being able to support longer addresses

author: pauld.9606
content: Yes, I was thinking about this migration. It will be a challenge in social-coordination. Will be interesting to observe.

author: pauld.9606
content:
> This disincentivizes doing the 2^80 work.
Oh, my mistake, not true in the case of not-yet-created counterfactual contracts. But those should migrate to CREATE3 anyway.

author: vorot93
content: a bit extra: but why didn't Ethereum opt into base58 for shorthand encoding of addresses?

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm not aware of any specific reasons or thought that went into the current 20-byte hex encoded format, and the subsequent backwards compatible checksum format which that evolved into
